user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAccept_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAccept_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *sock_token, const OS_object_token_t *conn_token,
                           OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    uint32                          operation;
    socklen_t                       addrlen;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *sock_impl;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;

    sock_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *sock_token);
    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *conn_token);

    operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE;
    if (sock_impl->selectable)
    {
        return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(sock_token, &operation, timeout);
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if ((operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE) == 0)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
        }
        else
        {
            addrlen       = Addr->ActualLength;
            conn_impl->fd = accept(sock_impl->fd, (struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData, &addrlen);
            if (conn_impl->fd < 0)
            {
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                Addr->ActualLength = addrlen;

                OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS(conn_token);
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAccept_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
void OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             os_flags;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_flags = fcntl(impl->fd, F_GETFL);
    if (os_flags == -1)
    {
        /* No recourse if F_GETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
        OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_GETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    else
    {
        os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS;
        if (fcntl(impl->fd, F_SETFL, os_flags) == -1)
        {
            /* No recourse if F_SETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
            OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_SETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
        }
    }

    impl->selectable = true;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I did not mark other fragments for investigation because they are normal, potentially reachable runtime paths and/or error handling that cannot be proven unreachable from the provided code: the accept() call and its subsequent fd < 0 error handling are standard runtime outcomes (accept can succeed or fail); updating Addr->ActualLength and calling OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS(conn_token) are correct follow-up actions when accept succeeds; the initial OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET() calls and variable declarations are obviously reachable; and the use of OS_SelectSingle_Impl() when selectable is true is a valid control flow that can legitimately return different results. The only fragments that raise a concern for unreachable-code analysis are the ones listed: the explicit else branch that unconditionally sets return_code = OS_SUCCESS (which may be dead if sockets are always made selectable), the pre-initialization of operation together with the select/else logic, the timeout branch that may never be taken depending on selectable/Select implementation, and the assignment impl->selectable = true in OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl (which can make the non-selectable branch impossible). These should be investigated together (socket initialization paths and OS_SelectSingle_Impl behavior) to determine whether any branch is truly unreachable.
